Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Do-It-Yourself Biology, Deliberation and Democracy

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
General Audience Summary

This dissertation project will develop a case study of citizen deliberations about the governance of science by focusing on Do-It-Yourself Biology, a form of amateur science that makes relatively simple biotechnology practices accessible to individuals who are not affiliated with academic or corporate laboratories. The researcher will explore how the DIY Biology network defines synthetic biology and its governance using archival research and ethnographic methods. Issues to be explored include how the network relates to academic and corporate scientists and other stakeholders, how US and EU regulatory structures inform and respond to the network, and the consequences these negotiations pose for genetically modified organisms and the future of genetic sciences. The study will generate data that will be useful to scholars, policymakers, and practitioners. The results of the study will be disseminated to academic audiences through journals such as Social Studies of Science, Public Understanding of Science, and Science Communication. They will also be disseminated in widely accessible newspaper and magazine articles. In addition, the researcher will develop an online wiki that compiles links to local, national and international regulations pertaining to laboratories that work with transgenic organisms in order to enable practitioners to add more links over time.

Technical Summary

Using archival and ethnographic methods, the researcher will explore how DIY Biology in the San Francisco area, which serves as the primary site of the US phase of the project; the region plays a pivotal role in the development of biotechnology and microelectronics, two streams that are converging in synthetic biology. Copenhagen, Denmark, serves as the primary site of the EU phase of the project due to its leadership in developing contemporary biotechnology, in formulating national and international biotechnology policies, and in encouraging active citizen participation in the regulatory process. Complementing an ethnographic approach with archival study will extend this research back in time to highlight how DIY Biology echoes or diverges from historical conceptions of microelectronics and biotechnology. The project will contribute to multi-disciplinary conversations about how emerging technologies are constituted, legitimized and governed, and how democracies operate. By positioning citizens as practitioners of scientific techniques, DIY Biology offers an opportunity to reconsider scientist-citizen interactions in the context of governance. The project will shed light on the shifting interactions between science and politics in different cultural contexts, on what motivates people to deliberate and how people experience deliberation in their daily lives, and on the effects their deliberations have on governance systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
National Science Foundation (NSF) funding enabled the Co-Principal Investigator (co-PI) to conduct a multi-sited ethnography. Ethnography is a form of qualitative research that includes interviews, participant observation, and analysis of artifacts. In the United States, the researcher conducted ethnographic research for five weeks at a do-it-yourself biology (DIY bio) laboratory in New York, in summer 2015. She served as an apprentice to the individuals working there and helped the laboratory’s executive director conceptualize metrics that would demonstrate the value that the lab provides. In addition, she visited the San Francisco Bay area and Silicon Valley for two weeks in August 2015 to talk with people who have been involved with the development of the Glowing Plant, the first crowd-funded genetically modified organism.

In the European Union, the co-PI conducted four weeks of ethnographic research at a small DIY bio laboratory in Copenhagen, Denmark. This allowed her to revisit several individuals who participated in previous research she conducted in summer 2014, while assisting and spending time with individuals who had become affiliated with the laboratory in the intervening time. She also interviewed academic and corporate affiliates of this lab, as well as people associated with formal governing bodies such as the Danish Board of Technology and more informal governing bodies such as the university laboratories that help define institutional norms of practice.

Applying multi-sited ethnographic methods enabled the researcher to correct an assumption prevalent in previous research and in media coverage: that DIY bio is separate from academic and corporate science. She argues, instead, that DIY bio is a consequence of standardization and commercialization of tools that has taken place since the 1980s—changes that are easier to see in DIY laboratories, but not necessarily absent from better-established sites of scientific practice. From this perspective, the ethical and organizational negotiations taking place in DIY laboratories are relevant to the overall governance of biotechnology.

Research participants across all sites included scientists working in academic, corporate, and DIY laboratories; artists and designers; scholars of governance; entrepreneurs; engineers; and individuals who were new to DIY bio. Support from NSF allowed the co-PI to work with these research participants not only across a much broader geographic distance, but also to document their activities over an extended period of time. Before receiving this grant, she had forged relationships with DIY bio practitioners in New York, California, and Denmark in 2013 and 2014. Grant funds enabled her to revisit these research sites to document their activities over a much longer time period. As a result, her doctoral dissertation offers a rare glimpse not only into how DIY bio is practiced, but how DIY laboratories are evolving over time. 

The individuals who generously agreed to participate in this research are weighing complex questions related to the social, ethical, and regulatory acceptability of manipulating the DNA of living beings. They often disagree about what is good, what is just, what is acceptable, and what is technically feasible. Furthermore, some of them are revising their perspectives over time. Rather than attempting to present a definitive snapshot of a rapidly-evolving field, the resulting dissertation highlights and reflects on issues that the co-PI and her collaborators have identified as worthy of consideration, in the hopes of contributing to broader and more inclusive conversations about the practice and governance of genetic manipulation.
